BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 28, 1922
AS TO SPORTS PUBLICITY, AMATEUR AND PROFESSIONAL
There was instituted, last fall, among the daily papers of a number of our largest cities, a most commendable movement, concerning
the free publicity given professional sports.
From force of habit, rather than from necessity, the newspapers
have become the free advertising slaves of professional sport promoters. Whereas, the scarcity of readable news has, on a number of
occasions, forced a wide use of this sort of material, custom is primarily responsible for the misuse of so much space.
It was pointed out in a local daily, several months ago, that
custom had forced the press to reserve a regular amount of space
for the free advertising of the motor industry, the stage, etc.
Some of the bolder leaders of the above-mentioned movement
have broken free from the yoke and have declared themselves as
against widespread free-advertising for other than amateur affairs.
Inasmuch as the publishers are directly dependent upon their
paid advertisers, it is, of course, impossible to ward off entirely the
attack hurled by the publicity agents of the various promoters.
It does seem, though, rather an unbalanced sort of publicity
that devotes from one to three pages in a single edition to the promotion of monied sports. Its only possible excuse is that "it advertises
the city."
We rather agree with the revolutionary editors who have cast
off the shackles, that the reading public would require but a single
season to be educated into being enthusiastic followers of amateur
sport, either of the sand-lot or collegiate variety.
In pushing non-professional sports, the press would not only
succeed just as well in advertising the city, hut would give a great
boost to a system that is serving, in a large measure, to make America's manhood physically better off.
A single column per issue should be a sufficient news item on any
professional sport. The press has the power of turning the "fan's"
dollar into a hopper providing the already overpaid professional with
more cash or of turning it into a machine designed to produce strong,
clean American citizens.
While there's life, there's hope, so there's a bare chance that
even the press may learn a thing or two in time.

SUPPORT THE SPRING SCHEDULE
Saturday marks the opening of a spring sport schedule which
promises to be the best in years. Much depends upon solid student
support, if this schedule is to be a success. Last fall the enthusiasm
of the undergraduate body helped carry a good football team to the
state gridiron championship. That same spirit of hearty support
and co-operation can overcome any difficulties which may appear this
spring. This loyal strain is not a thing new at Hopkins, but has
lately become active in manifold ways. Every class and each individual will prove equal to the occasion. The spring schedule will
be a success.

AS TO SPORTS PUBLICITY, AMATEUR AND PROFESSIONAL
There was instituted, last fall, among the daily papers of a number of our largest cities, a most commendable movement, concerning
the free publicity given professional sports.
From force of habit, rather than from necessity, the newspapers
have become the free advertising slaves of professional sport promoters. Whereas, the scarcity of readable news has, on a number of
occasions, forced a wide use of this sort of material, custom is primarily responsible for the misuse of so much space.
It was pointed out in a local daily, several months ago, that
custom had forced the press to reserve a regular amount of space
for the free advertising of the motor industry, the stage, etc.
Some of the bolder leaders of the above-mentioned movement
have broken free from the yoke and have declared themselves as
against widespread free-advertising for other than amateur affairs.
Inasmuch as the publishers are directly dependent upon their
paid advertisers, it is, of course, impossible to ward off entirely the
attack hurled by the publicity agents of the various promoters.
It does seem, though, rather an unbalanced sort of publicity
that devotes from one to three pages in a single edition to the promotion of monied sports. Its only possible excuse is that "it advertises
the city."
We rather agree with the revolutionary editors who have cast
off the shackles, that the reading public would require but a single
season to be educated into being enthusiastic followers of amateur
sport, either of the sand-lot or collegiate variety.
In pushing non-professional sports, the press would not only
succeed just as well in advertising the city, hut would give a great
boost to a system that is serving, in a large measure, to make America's manhood physically better off.
A single column per issue should be a sufficient news item on any
professional sport. The press has the power of turning the "fan's"
dollar into a hopper providing the already overpaid professional with
more cash or of turning it into a machine designed to produce strong,
clean American citizens.
While there's life, there's hope, so there's a bare chance that
even the press may learn a thing or two in time.
